raw_text:
Lasting influence of legend Charles
 
 Ray Charles, who has won a string of posthumous Grammy Awards, belonged to a pioneering generation of artists that had a huge influence on the course of rock and pop music.
 
 His sound encompassed so many styles - blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll, even country - and had a real impact on the nascent UK beat and R&B scenes.
 
 Compared in stature to Elvis Presley by some commentators, Charles' songs cast their spell on such 1960s stalwarts as Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, Eric Burdon and Van Morrison. His influence has extended to contemporary artists such as Norah Jones, with whom he recently recorded a duet. If James Brown was the godfather of soul, then Ray Charles was indisputably one of its founding fathers. Along with Sam Cooke, he was instrumental in bringing together the gospel fervour of the deep south Baptist church with the "devil's" music of R&B to pave the way for a new generation of soul artists.
 
 Without Charles, it is hard to imagine the tear-stained Atlantic R&B sound of Aretha Franklin, Otis Redding or Wilson Pickett. He was also a talented jazz composer, arranger and band leader, playing at the Newport Jazz Festival and Carnegie Hall and recording with noted jazz musicians such as Milt Jackson and David "Fathead" Newman. Unfortunately, he also shared another trait common among many jazz artists of the era - that of heroin addiction, which led to him being arrested in 1965. His string of 1950s Atlantic R&B successes included songs that would be covered by the first-generation rock 'n' roll greats, including I've Got A Woman (Roy Orbison, Elvis Presley) and Hallelujah, I Love Her So (Eddie Cochran). After the exuberance of his 1959 signature song What'd I Say, Charles turned towards a more pop-oriented style, recording Hoagy Carmichael's sentimental string ballad Georgia On My Mind, and the upbeat Hit The Road Jack.
 
 He also won acclaim in the country arena with his interpretations of Hank Williams standards such as Your Cheating Heart and You Win Again. More than 40 years after its release, his 1962 ABC album Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music is still regarded as a classic. His version of Don Gibson's I Can't Stop Loving You topped the pop and R&B charts in the US. In 1972, he made a rare foray into protest songs with his album A Message from the People.
 
 On it, he took a stand on poverty and civil rights - echoing similar recordings of the era from progeny such as Stevie Wonder, James Brown, Curtis Mayfield and Marvin Gaye. More than 20 years later, he would embrace contemporary production with his 1993 album My World, which featured hip-hop beats - although Charles claimed at the time not to know what hip-hop was. Among the tributes that poured in from all sections of the music world when Charles died aged 73 in June 2004 was one from his friend, the producer Quincy Jones, who described him as a "brother in every sense of the word". "There will never be another musician who did as much to break down the perceived walls of musical genres as much as Ray Charles did," he said. Former Manfred Mann singer Paul Jones, who sang on 1960s hits such as Come Tomorrow and Sha La La, said Charles was one of his heroes. "I'm quite sure my own writing was influenced by him," he told BBC News Online. "I would put money on the proposition that Ray Charles will have an influence on music forever."
llama3.2:1b: Ray Charles had a lasting influence on rock and pop music, encompassing various styles including blues, gospel, jazz, and R&B. He had a significant impact on UK beat and R&B scenes, influencing artists such as Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, Eric Burdon, and Van Morrison. His songs have been covered by many 1960s and contemporary artists, including Norah Jones with whom he recently recorded a duet. Charles was also a talented jazz composer and arranger. He won posthumous Grammy Awards for his contributions to music.
llama3.2:3b: Charles won numerous posthumous Grammy Awards and had a significant influence on rock and pop music. He blended various styles, including blues, gospel, jazz, and country, which impacted artists such as Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, Eric Burdon, and Norah Jones. As one of the founding fathers of soul, Charles' music paved the way for future generations. His contributions include shaping the sound of Aretha Franklin, Otis Redding, and Wilson Pickett, as well as recording with jazz musicians such as Milt Jackson and David "Fathead" Newman.
gemma2:2b: Ray Charles was a pioneering artist who significantly impacted rock and pop music. His diverse musical style encompassed blues, gospel, jazz, and others, influencing artists like Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, Eric Burdon, Van Morrison, Norah Jones, and many others.  Charles' influence extended to the soul genre, paving the way for artists like Aretha Franklin and Otis Redding. He was also a talented jazz composer and bandleader who recorded with renowned musicians. Despite his success, Charles battled heroin addiction and its legal consequences.  His legacy includes hits like "What'd I Say," "Hallelujah, I Love Her So," "Georgia On My Mind," and "I Can’t Stop Loving You." He also explored country music, releasing a classic album of the genre. Furthermore, Charles used his platform to address social justice issues with songs on his 1972 album "A Message from the People." He was celebrated for breaking down musical barriers and left a lasting impact on generations of artists.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
### Summary

Ray Charles, a pioneering artist who achieved posthumous fame in the 1960s, has had a profound impact on rock and pop music. His versatility encompassed styles like blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll, and country music, which he influenced such artists as Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, Eric Burdon, and Van Morrison. Charles' influence extended to contemporary artists like Norah Jones and his duet with Joe Cocker on "What's My Name." He also left a legacy in jazz, contributing to his version of Hank Williams' song "I Can't Stop Loving You" in 1962 and making a rare foray into protest songs. Charles was known for his stand against poverty and civil rights, as reflected in works such as "Your Cheating Heart" and "You Win Again." He died at age 73 in June 2004 during a concert in Atlantic City with over 500,000 fans and received tributes from all sections of the music world.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Charles's diverse musical style including blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll, country music, and R&B influenced numerous artists throughout his lifetime. His songs had a profound impact on 1960s music and paved the way for contemporary soul acts such as Norah Jones. Charles was also a talented jazz composer and arranger, playing at the Newport Jazz Festival and Carnegie Hall and recording with noted jazz musicians. Although he struggled with heroin addiction in his later years, Charles remained an influential figure in American music history.
qwen2.5:3b: Ray Charles, a pioneering artist who won posthumous Grammy Awards, had a profound impact on rock and pop music through his fusion of blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll, and country. He influenced UK beat and R&B scenes and was compared to Elvis Presley by commentators. His songs inspired artists like Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, Eric Burdon, Van Morrison, Norah Jones (who he recently recorded with), Aretha Franklin, Otis Redding, Wilson Pickett, and contemporary acts such as Norah Jones. Charles is considered one of the founding fathers of soul music alongside Sam Cooke for bringing together gospel fervor with R&B. He composed jazz pieces and played at Newport Jazz Festival and Carnegie Hall. His 1950s Atlantic R&B hits included classics covered by rock 'n' roll legends. Charles also excelled in country music, covering Hank Williams standards. Later, he made a protest song album that echoed similar efforts from the era. Despite his artistic achievements, Charles struggled with heroin addiction and faced legal troubles in 1965. His legacy spans various musical genres including R&B, pop, jazz, country, and hip-hop, influencing music forever according to his friend Quincy Jones.
opencoder:1.5b:
Ray Charles, a pioneer of rock and pop music, has been a driving force behind the development of modern music forms. His career spanned decades with multiple Grammy Awards - four of which included in 1975, 1982, 1993, and 2004. He had considerable influence on the course of rock and pop music, particularly in the early 20th century where he played as a solo artist. His influences extended to contemporary artists such as Norah Jones. Charles was indisputably one of its founding fathers. His influence also extended to artists like James Brown who shared a similar trait. He also won an acclaim for his interpretations of certain songs, and made a rare foray into protest songs with his album A Message from the People.

The rest of the text provided in the original question is summarized in the following response.
smollm:1.7b: The last sentence is a summary of the text, preserving key ideas and details. It captures the essence of the text without explaining or justifying it. The summary does not provide additional information, explanations, or reasoning processes. Instead, it presents the main points in a concise and clear manner.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize the given text. Let me read through it carefully.

The text is about Ray Charles and his influence on rock and pop music. He was a pioneering artist in the 1960s who had a big impact on both the UK and R&B scenes. His songs spanned various genres like blues, gospel, jazz, etc., which influenced many musicians of that time.

He was compared to Elvis Presley, and his influence extended beyond country artists to soul artists. He's also a jazz musician, played at notable events, and has a legacy in rock 'n' roll through his songs and later work.

His 1950s R&B successes are still famous today, like "I've Got A Woman" and others. He also influenced pop-oriented styles with his 1962 album and the song "Georgia On My Mind." His influence lasts until now, even though he died in 2004.

In summary, Ray Charles was a key figure who transformed music during that era through various genres and continues to shape it today.
</think>

Ray Charles was a pivotal figure in the 1960s who revolutionized rock and pop music with his innovative sound and influence. He influenced both the UK and R&B scenes, blending blues, gospel, jazz, and rock 'n' roll, while also inspiring soul artists. His legacy continues to shape music through his 1950s R&B hits like "I've Got A Woman" and his 1962 modern rock album Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music, which remains iconic today.
tinyllama:1.1b: The late iconic singer and songwriter Ray Charles, a pioneering figure in blues, gospel, jazz, rock & roll, and country music, had a significant influence on various styles of music during his lifetime. His sound encapsulated many different styles ranging from blue-ish go-go to jazz, country, R&B, and even contemporary artists like Norah Jones and Van Morrison. He was a vital contributor to the formation of soul music, having recorded songs that influenced countless other soul artists such as Sam Cook and James Brown. Without Charles, it is hard to imagine the vibrant Atlantic R&B sound of Aretha Franklin, Otis Redding, Wilson Pickett, and others. His string of jazz-based hits and country-pop smashes included songs that were covered by rock 'n' roll pioneers such as Roy Orbison, Elvis Presley, Edith "Ella" Cohrson, and Iggy Pop. Charles was also a talented jazz composer, arranger, bandleader, and jazz musician who played at the Newport Jazz Festival and Carnegie Hall and recorded with noted jazz musicians such as Milton Jackson and David "Fahead" Newman. Despite his heroin addiction, he shared a similar trait to many jazz artists of the era and was arrested for drug-related charges in 1965. He is remembered for his significant contributions to popular music, which have influenced numerous generations of artists in various genres.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Ray Charles is known as a pioneering figure in the world of music, particularly within the realms of blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll and R&B. Born in Hickory, North Carolina in 1934, Charles was an influential artist who had a profound impact on many prominent musicians throughout his career.

During his lifetime, Ray Charles released over 80 albums that showcased his incredible range of talent, covering styles such as blues, gospel, jazz and rock 'n' roll to create a unique sound that remains celebrated today. His songs have been covered by countless artists, and his legacy lives on through the legions of musicians who have been inspired by his music.

One of Ray Charles' most iconic hits is "What'd I Say," which became a staple in blues repertoire and has had a significant impact on many other artists throughout time. His version of this song was featured on the 1962 ABC album Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music, and it became a classic that has been covered by numerous artists over the years.

Over the course of his career, Ray Charles made numerous forays into different genres, including pop and R&B. His rendition of Don Gibson's "I Can't Stop Loving You" reached the top of the charts in 1962, a testament to his versatility as an artist. He also released albums that tackled issues such as poverty and civil rights, which resonated with listeners across the globe.

Overall, Ray Charles was an instrumental figure in shaping the music industry and leaving a lasting impact on generations of musicians who have been inspired by his work. His music has had a profound impact on countless artists, and his legacy will continue to inspire future generations of musicians for years to come.
phi:2.7b: Ray Charles, a pioneering artist who had a huge impact on rock and pop music, blended blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll, and country in his sound. He influenced a string of posthumous Grammy Award winners such as Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, Eric Burdon, and Van Morrison. Charles was instrumental in bringing together the southern gospel fervour with R&B to pave the way for a new generation of soul artists. He also recorded at the Newport Jazz Festival and Carnegie Hall with jazz legends like Milt Jackson and David "Fathead" Newman. However, he struggled with heroin addiction that led to him being arrested in 1965. Despite this setback, Charles' Atlantic R&B successes included songs that would be covered by rock 'n' roll greats such as Elvis Presley and Roy Orbison. He also won acclaim in the country arena with his interpretations of Hank Williams standards like Your Cheating Heart and You Win Again. His most recent album, My World, featured hip-hop beats. Charles took a stand on poverty and civil rights through his songs A Message from the People, which became a classic. Quincy Jones called him a "brother in every sense of the word" who broke down the walls of musical genres. Paul Jones said that Ray's influence could be seen in his music.
orca-mini:3b: Lasting influence of legend Charles Ray Charles, who had a significant impact on rock and pop music with his versatile sound encompassing many styles such as blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll, and country. He was a talented jazz composer, arranger, and band leader playing at the Newport Jazz Festival and Carnegie Hall, recording with notable jazz musicians such as Milt Jackson and David "Fathead" Newman. Charles also won acclaim in the country arena with his interpretations of Hank Williams standards such as Your Cheating Heart and You Win Again. He became a pioneer in the genre of soul music with his 1962 ABC album Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music, which is still regarded as a classic. Charles' version of Don Gibson's I Can't Stop Loving You topped the pop and R&B charts in the US.
hermes3:3b: Charles Ray Charles, founding father of soul & influential rock/pop artist, shaped 60s music scene with his diverse styles. His impact can be seen in artists like Norah Jones and modern soul musicians.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Ray Charles was a groundbreaking musician whose sound blended various styles, including blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll, and country. He had a significant impact on generations of artists and contributed to the development of soul and R&B music. His influence can be seen in the works of contemporary artists like Norah Jones and in the tear-stained Atlantic R&B sound of Aretha Franklin, Otis Redding, or Wilson Pickett. Charles was also a talented jazz composer, arranger, and bandleader. He struggled with heroin addiction and faced legal issues in the 1960s but remained influential throughout his career. In 1993, he released an album that embraced contemporary production, hip-hop beats, despite not knowing what hip-hop was at the time of its creation. Ray Charles died in 2004 at the age of 73, leaving a lasting legacy in the music world.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Ray Charles was a pioneering musician whose influence spanned multiple genres, including blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll, and country. His impact shaped the UK beat and R&B scenes and inspired artists like Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, and Van Morrison. Alongside Sam Cooke, he helped merge gospel with R&B, laying the foundation for soul music and influencing legends such as Aretha Franklin and Otis Redding. A talented jazz composer and bandleader, he performed at prestigious venues and collaborated with noted jazz musicians. Despite struggles with heroin addiction, Charles produced numerous hits, including "What'd I Say," "Georgia On My Mind," and "Hit The Road Jack." His 1962 album *Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music* remains a classic, and he later explored protest music and contemporary production. When he passed away in 2004, tributes poured in, with Quincy Jones praising his genre-defying contributions. His legacy continues to shape music, ensuring his influence endures.
stablelm2:1.6b:
Ray Charles, known for Grammy-winning posthumous performances in rock and pop music, had a significant impact on early UK beat and R&B scenes. His versatile style encompassed blues, gospel, jazz, and country genres. As tall as Elvis Presley, Charles' songs influenced artists like Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, Eric Burdon, and Van Morrison. With James Brown, he was one of the founding fathers of soul music, integrating gospel fervor with R&B to pave the way for a new generation of soul musicians. Without him, legendary soul artists like Aretha Franklin or Otis Redding might not exist.

Charles also showed talent as a jazz composer, arranger, and band leader, collaborating with notable jazz musicians like Milt Jackson and David "Fathead" Newman at venues such as the Newport Jazz Festival and Carnegie Hall. Unfortunately, he battled heroin addiction, which led to his arrest in 1965, although his Atlantic R&B success included hit songs like "I've Got a Woman" (Roy Orbison) and "Hallelujah, I Love Her So" (Eddie Cochran). He transitioned towards pop-oriented music, recording ballads like Georgia On My Mind and Hit The Road Jack.

Charles also enjoyed country music, with interpretations of Hank Williams standards such as "Your Cheating Heart" and "You Win Again." His album A Message from the People delved into social issues and echoed recordings by other musicians of his era. He later embraced contemporary production with his 2013 album My World, featuring hip-hop beats; however, he claimed not to know what hip-hop was at the time.

Quincy Jones, a close friend and collaborator of Charles, described him as "brother in every sense of the word" and one of the most influential musicians who broke down the perceived walls between musical genres. Ray Charles' influence on music forever will be remembered by his fans and admirers worldwide.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Ray Charles, a pioneering artist from the 1950s and 1960s, significantly impacted rock, pop, soul, jazz, and country music. Known for his versatile sound incorporating blues, gospel, jazz, R&B, and even country elements, Charles' influence extended to artists like Joe Cocker, Steve Winwood, Eric Burdon, Van Morrison, Norah Jones, Aretha Franklin, Otis Redding, and Wilson Pickett. His songs were comparable to those of Elvis Presley, cementing his status as a founding father of soul music alongside Sam Cooke. Charles' collaborations with gospel artists helped bridge the gap between religious and secular music.

Beyond his R&B success, he was a renowned jazz composer, arranger, and band leader who performed at prestigious venues like Newport Jazz Festival and Carnegie Hall. However, Charles battled heroin addiction, leading to his 1965 arrest. His early 1950s hits, such as "I've Got A Woman" and "Hallelujah, I Love Her So," were covered by first-generation rock 'n' roll stars.

After transitioning towards a more pop-oriented style in the late 1950s, Charles recorded sentimental jazz ballads like "Georgia On My Mind" and upbeat tracks such as "Hit The Road Jack." His album "Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music" (1962) remains a classic. In 1972, he released protest music on "A Message from the People," addressing poverty and civil rights.

In 1993, Charles embraced contemporary production with his album "My World," which featured hip-hop beats, though he claimed not to understand the genre at the time. His impact was universally recognized; Quincy Jones described him as a "brother in every sense of the word" and a musician who broke down musical genre barriers. Paul Jones from Manfred Mann echoed this, crediting Charles as one of his heroes and influencing his own songwriting. It is widely agreed that Ray Charles' influence on music will endure forever.
reference: If James Brown was the godfather of soul, then Ray Charles was indisputably one of its founding fathers.Ray Charles, who has won a string of posthumous Grammy Awards, belonged to a pioneering generation of artists that had a huge influence on the course of rock and pop music."I would put money on the proposition that Ray Charles will have an influence on music forever."Among the tributes that poured in from all sections of the music world when Charles died aged 73 in June 2004 was one from his friend, the producer Quincy Jones, who described him as a "brother in every sense of the word".Former Manfred Mann singer Paul Jones, who sang on 1960s hits such as Come Tomorrow and Sha La La, said Charles was one of his heroes.His sound encompassed so many styles - blues, gospel, jazz, rock 'n' roll, even country - and had a real impact on the nascent UK beat and R&B scenes.More than 20 years later, he would embrace contemporary production with his 1993 album My World, which featured hip-hop beats - although Charles claimed at the time not to know what hip-hop was.Without Charles, it is hard to imagine the tear-stained Atlantic R&B sound of Aretha Franklin, Otis Redding or Wilson Pickett.After the exuberance of his 1959 signature song What'd I Say, Charles turned towards a more pop-oriented style, recording Hoagy Carmichael's sentimental string ballad Georgia On My Mind, and the upbeat Hit The Road Jack.
